Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Programs in the Chemical Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
University of Michigan chemistry professors Brian Coppola and Melanie Sanford co-direct the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site in Interdisciplinary Chemistry, funded by the Chemistry Division of NSF. This is a continuation of a long established program that began in 1989. In this renewal, 15 students from around the United States, recruited primarily from settings where individuals do not have the opportunity to carry out graduate-level research, spend 10 weeks engaged as full-fledged participants in the department's research groups. There is a recruiting emphasis on women and students from underrepresented groups.
Additional activities (lectures, workshops, trips, and social events), offered jointly with other programs on- and off-campus, provide a broad integration into scientific and professional communities. A regional poster session is the culminating activity each summer.

Students participate in a diverse collection of modern research problems centered in the interdisciplinary chemical programs in the University of Michigan chemistry department, including chemical biology, organometallics, energy, sustainability, surface science, sensors, optics and imaging, RNA biochemistry, and ultrafast dynamics. The REU students have access to all of the research groups in the chemistry department, including interdisciplinary groups. REU students produce publishable results. The experience also gives participants confidence to remain in science, pursue graduate education, and ultimately to join the technically-trained workforce in academia, industry, or government laboratories.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the 2016-18 funding period, 40 students from around the United States, typically rising sophomores and juniors, and primarily from institutions where research opportunities are limited, will comprise our REU Site, which features interdisciplinary projects over the range of the chemical sciences. Our REU students joined the department's active undergraduate research cohort of 60-70 students in a 10-week program of research and professional development.  REU participants were recruited nationally, with an intentional, strategic emphasis on building a cohort that represents diverse backgrounds, settings, and experiences. During 1989-2018, our REU Site has hosted 302 undergraduate students as full-fledged collaborators in the well-equipped setting of a major research university.  We draw upon our strength as a research-intensive department to provide REU students with an authentic immersion in a graduate education setting. Our domestic summer research students are joined by a group of international undergraduate students from China, Germany, and Spain. Before arriving on campus, REU students worked with the REU Site Directors to establish a relationship with a research group; social networking provided the students with the opportunity to get to know one other before they arrive on campus. Other activities (lectures, workshops, trips, social events), offered jointly with other summer programs, provide a broad integration into scientific and professional communities. 

 

Students participated in a diverse collection of modern problems centered on our interdisciplinary research programs, including chemical biology, organometallics, energy, sustainability, surface science, sensors, optics & imaging, RNA biochemistry, and ultrafast dynamics. Consistently over the years, ~10% of publications from our department involving undergraduate co-authors have included an REU student. Our program assessments show that a full, authentic experience in a research-active department contributes to students’ confidence to pursue graduate studies, and to their ability to make informed decisions about choosing scientific careers. Students who are hesitant or uncertain of their ability to join and prosper in a large graduate environment show measurable and substantial change by the end of their 10-week experience. 

 

Our REU Site has successfully recruited and retained students in the PhD pipeline. We have tracked, at least in part, 286/302, or 95%, of the students from 1989-date. Of these 286 students, 110+ have their Ph.D. degrees, 31+ have M.S. degrees, 50+ are currently attending graduate school, 67+ at least earned the B.S. (with 54+ in industry), 16+ obtained their MD, DDS or JD, and 4 are still undergraduates. To date, 184/302 (61%) of our REU participants have been women, and 111/302 (37%) have been underrepresented minority students (51% during the 2016-18 funding period). We cooperate with internal (e.g., NSF-AGEP, “Growing STEM”) and external (e.g., U Delaware) programs to recruit qualified students from populations that are underrepresented in science.
